content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my cautious nature and preference for predictability, I would choose a strategy that ensures some consistency in earnings while minimizing the risk of getting zero. In this game, if both players choose R, we both earn 45$ per round. If we play B against each other, we earn 20$. However, if one player chooses R and the other B, the former gets nothing, and the latter receives 40$. Since I don't know my opponent's strategy, choosing R would expose me to the risk of earning zero in many rounds. On the other hand, choosing B guarantees that I will earn some money each round (20$) and reduces the chances of getting zero.

In a game with 75 rounds, I expect that I may lose some potential earnings by not taking the gamble on R, but I am willing to accept this trade-off for the greater security provided by choosing B. Thus, my choice is B{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In this round, since I and my opponent both chose B, we each earn 20$ again. I will continue to choose B in subsequent rounds as it minimizes the risk of earning zero while still ensuring some earnings in every round. The strategy of choosing B{B} appears to be a reasonable choice for someone who values security and predictability over maximizing potential earnings through taking risks.

In this round, since I chose B and my opponent chose R, I get 40$, while my opponent receives nothing. I would be tempted to take advantage of this situation and try to maximize my earnings by continuing to choose R in subsequent rounds. However, I am cautious and do not want to rely too heavily on the assumption that my opponent will continue to choose R. Therefore, I might switch back to choosing B to avoid taking unnecessary risks and maintain some predictability in my earnings. In this situation, I would choose R{B}.
